thread.title: What the Blues can learn from Demons rebuild
thread.title_full: What the Blues can learn from Demons rebuild

title: What the Blues can learn from Demons rebuild
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS CARLTON might have been taking lessons from Melbourne in more ways than one on Saturday. 
As the Blues suffered a disappointing 54-point loss to the Demons in their opening pre-season fixture of the summer, the gulf in class between the two sides was laid bare. 
But rather than feel demoralised during a period where excitement is building for most teams across the competition, Carlton can look back to where Melbourne was three years ago to see how quickly things can change. 
Under second-year coach Brendon Bolton, the Blues are taking a similar approach to the one adopted by Paul Roos when he arrived at the Demons in 2014. 
Melbourne demonstrated a crash course in going backwards to go forwards under Roos, stripping its list with an aggressive squad overhaul and implementing a defence-first on-field mentality. 
FOCUS ON STABILITY 
CONCEDING 122 points per game in 2013, Melbourne immediately set about leaking fewer scores against — even if it came at the expense of their offence. 
Although they scored less in 2014, they reaped immediate benefits going the other way, shipping 34 points fewer in their first year under Roos. 
Carlton saw similar progress last season, conceding 18 points per game under Bolton’s more recognisable defensive structure. 
“It’s the Melbourne blueprint,” club legend Garry Lyon told SEN on Monday. 
“You go back to the poorly performed Melbourne sides and how long it takes to rebuild. Only now are you seeing the fruits of their labours — it’s taken a long time. 
“Paul Roos went into Melbourne and said ‘what are we going to do here? I’m going to stop the bleeding’. He tried to shore up the defence, slow the game style and didn’t worry so much about the attacking.” Carlton coach Brendon Bolton on Saturday. Source: Getty Images 
The Blues have set about recruiting for their defence primarily from other clubs, even if the side’s main defensive drawcard — Jacob Weitering — was a top draft pick in 2015. 
Caleb Marchbank, 20, was a highly rated intercept defender at Greater Western Sydney, with Carlton hailing his arrival during last year’s trade period as somewhat of a coup. 
He joins his former teammate Lachie Plowman, also a top 10 draft pick, at the Blues via the Giants. 
The three form the pillars of Carlton’s future defensive structure and are well marshalled by the experienced Kade Simpson and emerging leader Sam Docherty across half back. 
GETTING YOUNGER 
CARLTON’S defensive stocks aren’t the only area undergoing a makeover. 
In losing 12 players to retirement, delistings and trades last year, the Blues shaved a lot of experience and depth from its list. 
It went from being the 10th oldest side in the competition to the third youngest, while Carlton also has the second fewest games per player in the league. 
“I think in the short-term they’re weaker,” Tim Watson added. 
“But long-term they’ll win out, because of the young talent they’ve brought in. 
“On talent alone, they’re near the bottom of the competition, which means they’re coming from a long way back.” 
That is perhaps coming mostly at the expense of their offence, as was to be expected when the Blues set about changing their future. 
“The concern is, at the other end of the ground, how are you going to kick a goal?” Lyon went on to ask on Monday. Marc Murphy made a successful return from injury on Saturday. Picture: Wayne Ludbey.   
Bar Levi Casboult, Carlton’s key forward stocks are young and inexperienced, though what they do have is a raft of early draft picks at their disposal. 
In addition to recruiting Jack Silvagni via the father-son rule in the 2015 draft, the Blues picked up Harry McKay (Pick 10) and Charlie Curnow (Pick 12). All three have shown glimpses of their potential as they continue their development up forward. 
THE FINAL PIECE 
AS Carlton set about recruiting its bookends for the next decade in 2015, the focus during last year’s trade period turned to the midfield. 
Melbourne — along with the likes of reigning premiers the Western Bulldogs — have exemplified the benefits of building a deep midfield. 
On Saturday, a reasonably young Blues on-ball brigade was simply overrun by the Demons, recording deficits in virtually every statistical category. 
It was an effort that left former Hawthorn great Jason Dunstall slamming the showing of Carlton’s midfielders, labelling their performance “an indictment” on their workrate. 
But with the likes of Marc Murphy and Bryce Gibbs leading the way, the Blues still have an experienced core that they can rotate through the middle. 
Patrick Cripps, who missed the weekend’s game with a back injury, leads the younger brigade, with fellow West Australians Sam Petrevski-Seton (Pick 6) and Zac Fisher (Pick 27) chosen first by the Blues during last year’s draft. 
According to Watson, building that midfield depth through the draft should remain a priority for the club in the years to come. 
“Obviously there’s a lot of work to do around the ball,” Watson said. 
“Every side needs to have a powerful engine in this game and that’s what they have to rebuild. 
“They’re trying to rebuild their spine at the same time. There’s a lot of work going on in terms of the renovation of this list, before they build themselves a sustainable base.”
